passages.text: Aug 2025: strong rally defying the weak seasonality

Key market drivers: CSI300/500/1000 ended August up \(10.3\% /13.1\% /11.7\%\) vs HSI/HSCEI's returns of \(1.2\% /0.7\%\) , with continuously improving onshore liquidity driving A- shares' valuation multiple expansion, as evidenced by rising market turnover, velocity, margin buying as a percentage of total turnover, and mutual funds' new issuance. Onshore investors we spoke with noted that more data confirming household asset relocation to equities and news on additional policy stimuli on the demand side could support the market in coming months, while US- China trade talks remain the key uncertainty in 4Q25. Earnings- wise, at end- August, consensus CSI300 2025E/2026E EPS growth was \(14.4\% /13.2\%\) y- y, flat vs \(15\% /12.3\%\) y- y at end- July, reflecting \(15.8x / 13.9x\) 2025/2026 P/E on consensus estimates (details on p.3). As of 30 August, \(100\%\) of CSI- 300 index market cap (300 out of 300) had reported 2Q25 results: 2Q25 EPS rose by \(3.1\%\) y- y, on \(1.1\%\) sales per share y- y, and NPM expansion of 18bps y- y. The beat/miss ratio was \(38\% /56\%\) (based on data from 211 constituents).

On flows, EPFR data recorded US\\$216mn net outflows from A- shares ending 22 August, led by Industrials, Consumer Discretionary, and Financials, while Materials recorded marginal net inflows over the period. But A- share margin buying as a percentage of A- share turnover further rose to \(11.3\%\) at end August from \(10.5\%\) at end July.

Key sector moves: IT \((+23\%)\) , Materials \((+13\%)\) , and Consumer Discretionary \((+10\%)\) were the top three performers; Energy \((1\%)\) , Utilities \((+2\%)\) , and Healthcare \((+3\%)\) were the bottom three.

Key macro data: July activity data underscored worsening supply- demand imbalances, with solid IP \((+5.7\%)\) y- y), soft retail sales \((+3.7\%)\) y- y, impact of trade- in subsidies on consumption has moderated, with auto sales being a significant drag), and struggling investment \((- 5.2\%)\) y- y, the largest monthly decline outside of 1Q20 in over two decades, with infrastructure/manufacturing FAI growth turning negative). July exports grew \(7.2\%\) y- y, with trend growth momentum slowing to \(0.7\%\) 3m- 3m saar from \(7.5\% /20.9\%\) in June/May, suggesting an unwinding of the 1H front- loading. Exports to the US declined \(6.6\%\) m- m_aa after the \(20\% +\) recovery in June. China's FX reserves fell US\\$25.2bn to US\\$3,292.2bn in July with continued gold purchases. USD/CNY eased to \(7.1\) , while the 10- year CGB yield rose to \(c1.78\%\) at end- Aug.
See page 5 for analyst certification and important disclosures, including non-US analyst disclosures.

With key China equity return drivers summarized on the front page, we detail below top and bottom ranked Wind A- share Level- 1 sector returns.
IT \((23\%)\) emerged into the strongest thematic play amidst abundant liquidity, with semis, hardware and software subsectors all recording strong performance.
Materials \((13\%)\) saw rare earth marching to new highs, and battery materials and chemicals benefiting from anti- involution.
Consumer Discretionary \((10\%)\) outperformed on autos and auto parts, partially thanks to the launch of the third batch trade- in subsidy with autos being the focus.
Energy \((1\%)\) underperformed amid a pull- back in crude oil price.
Utilities \((2\%)\) underperformed as a low- beta play.
Healthcare \((3\%)\) cooled down in the earnings season with generic drugs and CXOs seeing demand headwinds, while innovative drugs saw rising uncertainty in exports.
Figure 1: Market performance
Source:Wind 29 Aug 2025)J.P-Morgan 29 Aug 2025)
Figure 2: Wind A-Share Level 2 sector indices' MTD/YTD returns
Source:Wind 29 Aug 2025)J.P.Morgan 29 Aug 2025)Note:Data as of 29 Aug 2025
EPFR data recorded a US\$216mn net outflow from A- shares ending 22 August, led by Industrials, Consumer Discretionary, and Financials, while Materials recorded a marginal net inflow over the period.

The A- share margin financing balance as a percentage of A- share market cap improved to \(2.4\%\) at end August, vs c2.3% in July, and gross margin buying as a percentage of total A- share turnover further improved to \(11.3\%\) at end August vs \(10.5\%\) at end July. From 2016 to now, the margin balance as a \(\%\) of market cap has ranged from \(1.8\%\) to \(3.0\%\) with the median being \(2.3\%\) . In
Figure 6: A-share margin financing
Source: Wind (29 Aug 2025), J.P. Morgan (29 Aug 2025). Note: Data as of 29 Aug 2025.
Preliminary data showed Rmb26bn/8bn equity/balanced fund issuance in August, vs Rmb44bn/15bn in July.
Since 2016, annual fund-raising proceeds have ranged from Rmb40bn to Rmb376bn for equity funds (median at Rmb145bn), and from Rmb64bn to Rmb1,548bn (median at Rmb235bn) for balanced funds.

We estimate retail/controlling & strategic shareholders/ domestic financial institutions/foreign investors held \(42\% /43\% /12\% /3\%\) of A- shares' total market cap at end2024, respectively, based on company shareholding data and the PBOC's statistics on foreign investors' holdings of A- shares.
Figure 7: Onshore mutual fund issuance
Source: Wind (29 Aug 2025), J.P. Morgan (29 Aug 2025). Note: Data as of 29 Aug 2025.

At end- August, consensus CSI300's 2025/2026 EPS growth were \(14.4\% /13.2\% y - y\) , flat vs \(15\% /12.3\%\) at end- Jul, reflecting \(15.8x / 13.9x\) 2025/2026 P/E on consensus estimates. On 29 August, It traded at \(14.5x\) FTM P/E, or at c1.8SD vs median since 2016, and at 1.1x FTM PEG with FTM EPS y- y of \(13.6\%\) .
Figure 8: CSI300 FTM EPS revisions
Source: Wind (29 Aug 2025), J.P. Morgan (29 Aug 2025).
Figure 9: CSI300 FTM P/E
Source: Wind (29 Aug 2025), J.P. Morgan (29 Aug 2025).
Figure 10: CSI300 FTM P/E and EPS by sector
Source: Wind (29 Aug 2025), J.P. Morgan (29 Aug 2025).
Figure 11: CSI- 300's consensus PE- EPS metrics vs other markets

Economic and political reviewAverage one- year/10- year CGB YTM edged up by 1bp/7bps in August. July TSF disappointed as new loan creation recorded the first contraction in two decades. Household and corporate loans were both very weak. Loans to households contracted Rmb489bn, with - Rmb383bn for short- term loans, and - Rmb110bn for medium- to- long- term loans. This reflects general softness in both consumer spending and home purchase demand. Loans to corporates ticked up Rmb60bn, despite the contraction in both short- term (- Rmb550bn) and medium- to- long- term (- Rmb260bn) loans.

On the demand side, retail sales growth slowed further to \(3.7\%\) y- y, down from this year's peak of \(6.4\%\) in May. The NDRC announced the third batch of trade- in subsidies of Rmb69bn for 3Q (vs Rmb81bn for 2Q), continuing to support sectors such as household electronic appliances, communication products, cultural and office products, and furniture. However, the growth impulse appears to have moderated across most categories. Sales of self- incentivized consumer goods remained weak, with clothing and footwear growing less than \(2\%\) y- y. Catering and restaurant spending recorded around \(1\%\) y- y in June and July, partly due to tightened rules on public- sector employees' dining out activities.

Fixed investment fell \(0.3\%\) y- y in the month of July (the first monthly contraction in five years). Year- to- date manufacturing FAI growth has slowed to \(6.2\%\) oya. Infrastructure FAI dropped \(5.2\%\) oya, the first single- month contraction in 3.5 years. Year- to- date infrastructure FAI growth slipped to \(3.2\%\) oya. The real estate FAI contraction was not a surprise, though the magnitude also widened, to - 17.2%oya (vs - 11% on average in 1H).

On trade, July exports slowed less than expected (- 1.9% m- m sa, \(+0.7\%\) 3m- 3m saar), concentrated in low- end consumer goods, mechanical/electrical, and high- tech products. By destination, exports to the US fell \(6.6\%\) m/sa, while those to the EU (- 1.5%) and ASEAN (- 4%) also eased.

Industrial production aligned closely with our expectations, rising \(5.7\%\) oya or \(0.4\%\) m/sa (vs consensus: \(6.0\%\) ), indicating that the supply- side growth engine remains solid. Sector- wise, the expansion was primarily led by high- tech manufacturing, rail/ship/ aircraft transport equipment, electric machinery, ICT electronics equipment, and autos. Product- wise, production of industrial robots, NEVs, solar cells, and

integrated circuits continued to excel, while traditional raw materials sectors such as crude oil, coal, and cement remained lackluster. Additionally, the service production index rose a solid \(5.8\%\) y- y in July.

On inflation, June headline CPI recorded flat growth \((0\%)\) in both \(y\) - y and \(y\) m- m sa terms, moderating from \(0.1\%\) in June, dragged by food prices. The expected sequential PPI uptick did not occur, as PPI fell by \(0.2\%\) m- m sa, maintaining \(y\) - y at \(3.6\%\) , partly because high temperatures and rainfall slowed construction and increased hydropower use.
Figure 12: China consumer confidence and SME development
Source: Wind (29 Aug 2025), J.P. Morgan (29 Aug 2025).
Figure 13: Chinese government bond yield to maturity (CGB YTM)
Source: Wind (29 Aug 2025), J.P. Morgan (29 Aug 2025).

Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating.
